Content: Prove: $$\cos A + \cos B + \cos C + \cos (A+B+C) = 4 \cos \frac{A+B}{2} \cos \frac{B+C}{2} \cos \frac{A+C}{2}$$ Geometrically. I found the algebraic solutions here but I want to figure out how to calculate the above using geometrical arguments of complex numbers/ vectors. Some hints of geometry I figured out already: $\frac{A+B}{2}$ is equidistant in angle mangitude from $A$ and $B$ , that is $|\frac{A+B}{2} -A| = | \frac{A+B}{2} - B|$ , similar results hold for the other angle averages. We may think of the above as summing the projections of three unit vectors onto the x-axis: $ \left( \tau(A) + \tau(B) + \tau(C) + \tau( A+B+C)\right) \cdot \hat{i}$ , where $\tau(\phi)$ is the unit vector making angle $\phi$ with the x-axis Related , related
